I would encourage this dancer to have more attack in their movement. Sometimes their forearm feels disconnected from the rest of the body, so having attack and energy and presence throughout the entire body would help the overall look and feel of the dance and create more fluidity throughout the movement. I would encourage the dancer to spot and look the direction they intend on going to create very consistent patterns on the floor. I would encourage this dancer for the step-step touch to plie even more so then they can use their hips on a pendulum swing. Here I will repeat my earlier comments about grounding, about hip articulation, about power and strength through the movement, about using the back and extending through the arms, all of that wonderful stuff. I think this dancer could articulate their hips even further and swivel them, and they can do that by, of course, pliéing their legs so they have more range of motion to be able to move those hips. I would encourage this dancer to really think about using their rib cage and having strength and power from their back all the way to their fingertips and having strength and power throughout their arms.

I would encourage the dancer again to plie and to think about their head placement and use their head as a guiding anchor to be able to turn and also thinking about even really sinking in that hip to be able to pivot around to create a more seamless and flowing transition which gives the air of professional dance. I would encourage the dancer to think deeply about their arm placement. It seems like one arm is moving and then the other isn't. So making sure that both arms are moving consistently or over-exaggerating that you only want one arm to move. I would encourage this dancer to really plie through their legs to have more grounding, but also to really deeply do some work about musicality, embodying the rhythm. It seems like they know the rhythm, but they're not truly embodying it. So really practicing those isolations, just moving those hips to that music, moving that torso and that rib cage, those shoulders, that head, those knees and those legs, so they can all work in unison to really create that musicality, that embodied musicality. I would repeat my previous comment regarding musicality. Here, I would encourage the dancer, again, to think about musicality. Their feet is moving to the rhythm, but their hips and torso are not. So this takes away from the dynamic quality of the movement. And this is labeled advanced choreography, which I don't think it's properly labeled. This appears more of a basic choreography to me. I would encourage the dancer to plié through their legs. If they plié'd more, they would be able to sway their hips and create a more dramatic feeling in this choreography.
